description:
What a hidden gem! A friend and I came for lunch today. I had the lamb curry lunch plate which came with a helping of chickpeas, saffron rice, green salad plus naan. My friend had the shrimp curry that came with the same sides. The delicious lunch plates were about $15. Great variety! The staff members friendly and efficient. Just 2 days into offering the lunch specials. Will definitely go back! 

Check out the modern restrooms! Bonus if you are looking for private dining--elegant dining room for about 12 in the back. 

LOVED the "Visit Nepal" postcard that came with my bill. Turns out that the restaurant doubles as a base camp for travelers to Nepal. Check it out!
author: Emily M.

description:
Food: The chicken momos and the paneer chili appetizer were the highlights of the meal. Really delicious. For mains we ordered the daal bhat thali with goat (the goat was very tough. Only the curry was good), chicken tikka massala (since thing, meat was tough so I only soaked up the curry), and the bindhi curry (which was good, wish it was crispy). The garlic naan was yummy and much better than the parantha (too stuffed). 

Drinks: the Yeti tequila cocktail was good.

Ambiance: It's a pretty large space which is rare for SF so thats nice to actually have some ample space to eat. I wish the music choices were different. Seemed to hotel lobby music playing in the background all night

Service: Great! everyone was very friendly and attentive
author: Laura D.

description:
Despite the name, there is no yak on the menu at this hip Nepali-themed restaurant and bar. The staff were lovely and took the time to explain the restaurant and their history. The place was almost empty when my partner and I stopped in for lunch but don't let the lack of crowd trick you into thinking the food isn't great. They had some great cocktails on the menu and the bar was modern looking but it was too early to imbibe.

The food was excellent and the menu offered enough variety to keep even the pickiest eaters happy. The server made some great recommendations for dishes that go well together or are best for sharing. She deserves a lot of credit for this. I was a big fan of the Samosas ($8) which is served with some Tarkari and spicy sauces. I also liked the okra ($14) as it had more of a fresh, acidic taste to balance out all of the savory, warming flavors of the other dishes. The selection of meatless options was also a huge plus about the menu.

Overall, this place offers some great food, served by great people, in a great atmosphere. The assortment of Nepali pop music was a great scene setter as well. My only regret is not coming late enough in the day to enjoy some of the cocktails. I would gladly come back despite the fact there was no yak and no dancing.
author: Patrick G.

description:
They have some pretty delicious food here. I highly recommend sharing family style. 

- Chicken MOMO and Veggie MOMO - Both chicken and veggie MOMO were delicious. If you don't know what Momo is, it is essentially a dumpling. They give you a side of hot sauce to go with these dumplings and the hot sauce is extremely spicy. I repeat, extremely spicy. Just a dab will send your tongue to a different dimension. Use with caution. 

- Butter chicken - This dish is the most amazing thing ever. The flavor was just intoxicating and the chicken was so soft and tender. Order a side of paratha to dip the sauce into for the perfect bite.  

- Tandoori Plate (veggie and chicken) - This dish comprises of turmeric rice, mixed green salad, oven roasted vegetables, and chicken. I thought the dish was good, but not the most amazing among our order. The buttered chicken definitely beats this tandoori chicken. 

- Bhindi tarkari - This one is fried okra sautéed with onions, ginger, and garlic. If you like okra, this is a must try. It's one of their more popular vegetarian dishes. 

- Paulingo saag ray paneer - A big fan of this chopped spinach cooked with cumin and coriander on top of paneer. If you haven't had it, paneer cheese is just so good!

- Garlic naan - I was not much of a fan of their naan. I like crispy naan, and this one just wasn't crispy at all. I recommend the paratha as a substitute.

- Rose Lemonade - If you are looking for a nonalcoholic drink, this is the one to get. I typically don't like rose flavored anything, but I enjoyed this particular drink.
author: Julia K.

description:
Other then having the best name ever this place rocks. Great service and very good food. Lots of similarities to Indian but they use less sugar and overall the dishes are lighter. ... solid drinks as well 

Want to go back and some of the other items on the list.

Good luck Yak!!!
author: David B.

description:
Trendy restaurant in the Mission bordering Lower Haight. Their new bar (with updated cocktail list) was a delicious Nepali twist on traditional cocktails. The service was friendly and quick, and the food was enjoyable, but nothing to rave about. Likely wouldn't suggest it to friends, but wouldn't be opposed to going back. 

Recommendations: Chicken momo, beef chili appetizer, any of the curries

Pros: Big portions, helpful service, unique drinks

Okays: Not too much parking around 

Cons: Pork chili was overcooked and hard to chew
author: Perry H.

description:
Solid and delicious Nepali restaurant in the Mission neighborhood. It's a hidden gem!

The space feels very hip and laid back, with a lounge area with books. The restaurant seemed fairly new as it was easy to walk in for dinner. The ambiance is dim and very chill. It's good for a romantic date. 

I personally haven't heard of many Himalayan/Nepali restaurants in SF, but this one exceeded expectations! The menu has lots of options for fried appetizers, "Daal Bhat Thali" which includes curry, lentils, veggies, sides, tandoori plates and curries. They have buckwheat roti here - which is gluten free! They also have lots of vegan and plant based options too.

I wasn't feeling particularly hungry so I went with an appetizer, salad and roti. My friend got curry and the portions looked huge. The service was a little hit and miss. At times, it was really hard to reach out to our waiter. The Chicken Momo seemed popular here.

Bara ($8) - Black lentil puree patty mixed with ginger. Served with chicken gravy. So so good! 

Beet Salad ($14) - Roasted beets, arugula, kaffir cheese, krispy naan and sherry vinaigrette. The layout was a little weird for this dish since it came on a slim vertical plate. I found this a bit expensive for what you got.

Faphar ko Roti (Buckwheat) ($3) - Super delicious and a lot larger than I expected.

I'd love to come back to try their curry or thali dish. Definitely a unique spot in the area.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Nice laid back atmosphere during lunch time! Delicious momo and naan bread! Probably the best I've ever had! 

Why I was here // came with my friend and bf for lunch. We made reservations on yelp because it was a Sunday and we weren't sure if it was going to be very busy. We came at 12:15pm on a Sunday and it was pretty empty. It didn't get busy till around 1:30pm. 

Service // very friendly, just slow. Our mango lassi drinks took 20 minutes to come out. 

Atmosphere // love the decor! Very hip and atmospheric. The bar looks like it would be poppin at night! And the bathroom is super nice! The waitress also did mention that at night they get pretty busy for dinner/drinks.

Food // 
-chicken momo // 13.00 // absolutely delicious. Love that they also gave us the spicy sauce! Yummm! 10/10 would get this again 
-dhading chicken curry // 16.00// tasty! Love the consistency and flavors of this curry dish. Very comforting and paired well with naan. 
-lamb aloo // 18.00 // was a bit sad that I didn't like this dish more. The lamb was tender but the sauce was bland and watery. I'll pass. 
-garlic naan // 3.50 // best naan I've every had! Fluffy to perfection. I dream about this. 
-lachha paratha // 3.50 // very similar to the naan. It has some ingredient rolled in? They are very similar but personally the naan was better. 
-rice // 3.00 // it's just rice 
-mango lassi // 4.00 // took awhile to come out and had more yogurt than mango. More on the tart side and not very sweet. 

Overall // the experience was pleasant, food was good for the most part. I was a bit sad they didn't pack up our rice for us.... I might try and check out the dinner scene sometime, but I appreciated the super chill lunch, perfect for catching up with friends.
author: Emily T.

description:
tl;dr proudly Nepali restaurant serving up modern takes and traditional favorites with creative cocktails and incredibly soothing ambiance. They double as Nepalese travel advisors! So talk to them if you're interested.

WOW. Buckle in because this review is going to be LONG.

If y'all haven't noticed, the Nepalese culinary game in San Francisco is FIERCE. Dancing Yak is a new face, only opening in May of this year, but they're already making their mark. As we approached the restaurant, a local to the neighborhood noticed us walking over there and remarked that it's her favorite restaurant here.

The vibe when you walk in is chill and modern--they play trippy atmospheric music and the walls are decorated with psychedelic mushroom paintings and other such art. The servers are genuine and friendly. 

I'll start with the cocktail menu. They have an assortment of traditional cocktails with Nepalese/Indian flavors. In particular, I loved the 'Avalanche on Everest', a mango lassi with vodka and rose water--tart, fruity, and ever so slight hint of creaminess. I also liked the 'Cheers! To Progressing Nepal', a cocktail with arak and mint lemonade (if you like anise flavor, you'll love this). They have tons of other stuff I didn't get to try, like a bourbon and chai drink. But you should totally try it and let me know how it is!

Their menu is lovely. They've got unique dishes while still paying homage to the very traditional dhal baat and momo, and some Indian favorites as well. They have an a la carte curry menu, which I liked. Again, some unique dishes and some common favorites. We went for the pork belly, which was crispy and fork tender and had such a unique flavor. We also tried the saucy lollipops--big, succulent pieces of fried chicken with a very mildly spicy sauce. For our entrees, we went for the thali with lamb curry (the lamb was scrumptious) and the butter chicken, which was probably the most tender chicken I've ever had, and the sauce was amazing too. 

Dessert somehow also made an appearance--the kulfi (we got mango) is delicious and tastes like frozen lassi. We also got the pudding with almonds, but I wasn't very much a fan of that, I think because of just personal preference. It has the same texture as like a pudding made with ricotta cheese. It was still good, but not my kind of thing. They also have dessert that most Indian restaurants have too, like kheer and gulab jamun.

To top it all off, they give you a Nepali postcard with your check. On the back, you'll find tips and other info about traveling to Nepal, and they encourage you to reach out to them if you want to know more. To be honest, I'm very familiar with Nepali culture, and this is one of my favorite things about every Nepalese person I've ever met--they are proud of their culture in such an endearing and pure way. Nepalese people welcome everyone and are some of the most hospitable hosts you'll ever have. So let them introduce you to this wonderful, wild, and unique culture. You won't regret it! :)

Way to go, Dancing Yak, for being an outstanding representative of Nepal and its culture.
author: Claire C.

description:
Another Nepalese restaurant in the city! I came here on a Sunday night for dinner around 6 and was promptly seated. We just missed happy hour by a few minutes but nevertheless, I still wanted dinner. The interior and inside is great and spacious, with a couch/lounge area as the waiting area. Service was great but the kitchen overall was a little slow (took a while for the food to be brought out). Food is on the pricey side (ends up being ~18+ per dish as you would want to add a side of rice or naan to go with your sauce meat).

For food, I got the cashew chicken with garlic naan and the lamb patty skewers.  The naan was probably my favorite piece of the whole night, buttery and generous with garlic gloves. The cashew chicken was also super buttery and delicious. For the lamb patty skewers, we got it with the combo that came with roasted vegetables, salad, and rice. The rice was flavored and good. Not a big fan of the roasted vegetables, they were coated with some sauce and it was a little too overpowering. The skewers were good and I enjoyed the yogurt sauce that came with it. 

 Overall, the food was good but not my favorite Nepalese restaurant. I would definitely recommend this place for a date night or something similar-- since they have a full bar and the extra time for the food is great for talking with your date. Otherwise, there are cheaper and better options in the city.
author: Jenny N.

description:
This place was good, but not great.  Good food (some dishes were better than others), decent service (though a bit strange), and a spacious, pleasant atmosphere.

My husband and I shared the following (we had plenty of leftovers we took home):

1) Pork Belly appetizer - good, but not a standout 
2) Chicken lollipop - good, but also not a standout 
3) Bara - this was a unique dish - kind of like a thick dosa with a curry dipping sauce - decent 
4) Goat curry - very flavorful! My favorite dish
5) Chicken curry - pretty good 
6) Okra - tasty
7) Buckwheat roti - not what we expected - kind of like a thick dosa - I was not a fan
8) Laccha paratha - delicious, especially when paired with the goat curry

I thought my Avalanche Over Everest (I think) cocktail was good, and my husband's Don't Talk Yak cocktail was great.

The service was bizarre.  The hostess was a little strange in her interactions with us, and our waitress was also a bit odd.  When my husband asked our waitress about a particular cocktail, she said she wasn't too familiar with it, but when he then ordered it, she confidently stated that he would love it.  Later, when we ordered our meal, she awkwardly said to us, "wow, you guys are ordering a lot of food!"  Also, she forgot to tell us about the specials (we only realized this after she told the table next to us after we had already ordered).  On the plus side, the food came out quickly and table was cleared promptly.

The space was inviting and well-decorated.

Overall, this restaurant was all right, but it did not live up to the hype.
author: Barnali D.

description:
Came here for dinner recently and had a great experience!

We made a reservation same day and it was easy to book a table. When we arrived, the restaurant was busy but not packed on a Monday. It's a modern, trendy sort of atmosphere decorated with rich colors and chill music playing. The overall vibe is great!

We ordered a few appetizers to share and enjoyed them. We loved the Pork Belly Bhutwa, which was small chunks of excellently cooked pork belly with Indian seasonings. We also tried the Paneer Chili, and the Chicken and Vegetable Momos (the momos come 8 to an order and you can get a mixed order with both types). All portions were huge so we definitely over-ordered for 2 people!

For our main, we split the Daal Bhat Thali with lamb, which we enjoyed as well! It came with lamb curry, aloo gobi, black bean soup, greens and a lentil chip. This was also a huge amount of food! We also had the Lachha Paratha which was delicious and flavorful, like a denser naan. 

Our server was friendly and helpful, and did a great job welcoming us and giving us suggestions and recommendations. The cocktail menu was also creative, with some excellent options - I had the Don't Talk Yak, a bourbon-based drink with chai, honey and mint. Prices were also super reasonable given the quality of the food and the huge portions!
author: Christine G.

description:
When you didn't think there was a word cuter than "dumpling," here comes the word "momo" to describe a slightly inferior but still tasty meatball wrapped in dough. 

We came to Dancing Yak at lunchtime on a Monday, so there was nobody aside from another couple. We squeezed into one of the comfortable booths and ordered the daal bhat thali with goat curry and chicken momos. The waitress was really helpful in describing the dishes and also told us we could request more spiciness. 

Like I mentioned, the momos are an inferior dumpling. The skin is really thick, and you have to rely on the sauce to give it flavor. The meat inside was nice and soupy, The daal bhat thali is definitely a plate meant for two! There was so much on there, from the goat curry to the lentil stew, rice, and cauliflower. The flavor of the veggies were really muted, and the pickled stuff was super sharp and sour. The lentils are hearty but also slightly blander. My favorites were the goat curry and cauliflower, which were really good with the rice or eaten by the spoonful. 

The food is pretty unique and not as rich as Indian curries, so we left full but not stuffed.
author: Sophie W.

description:
We ordered the salmon curry and an eggplant dish. The salmon dish was okay but not exceptional, and while we both liked the eggplant, it was heavier and oilier than we would have liked. 

I had expected flavorful small dishes, with the ability to taste several different items, but as the dishes are all large, and there is no 'medley' option, we were only able to get two. 

I expected better with the high reviews, and left feeling like I had wasted a meal.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Glad to see another Nepalese restaurant in San Francisco.  It's by no means unheard of cuisine around these parts, but definitely unrepresented compared to something like Indian.  The menu has some familiar favorites (e.g. momos) as well as some things I haven't seen before (e.g. bara).

Bara: This was pretty tasty.  Reminded me of an uttapam, but a tad crispier on the outside and tad pastier on the inside.  Came with some chicken curry gravy, which paired just perfectly as a dip.

Chicken Curry Daal Bhat Thali: I couldn't commit to just one dish, so got the thali for variety.  The chicken curry had the same sauce as was paired with the Bara, but this time there was a bunch of tender chicken pieces.  Went nicely with fluffy rice.  The main veggies were cauliflower and potato in a drier curry (as opposed to the soupy chicken curry).  Lots of black lentils, which were so hearty they could be a meal unto themselves.  I found that sprinkling some of the fried potato sticks on top of the lentils was a great texture combo.  The papadum came in cute cones and added a nice crunch between curry bites.  Wasn't a big fan of the pile of greens; definitely the least flavorful, but I got full on everything else so no big deal.

Tropical Fruit Iced Tea: Unsweetened.  Very subtle fruit essence.  Light and refreshing.
author: Adam B.

description:
Nice ambience but a bit low energy for lunch. Great service. 

I would recommend the lamb Daal Bhat thali here - Nepalese dish with rice, black lentils, seasonal vegetables, seasonal green spinach, tomato aachar, papad. (I especially loved these cone shaped papad, which is a thin crispy papadum made with flour - I can eat 10 of these). The black lentils are wholesome and the lamb is tender without being overly greasy. Great for sharing between two people. 

Skip the chicken momos- equivalent of Chinese dumpling with thicker skin. I like the Chinese version much better.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
My friend I came of a Friday night. The ambiance is casual and dressy. There are booth settings, bar and table for 2 of needed.

They take reservations.. on yelp or by phone. They have a nice waiting area with sofa and chair. Each table has a lighted flower candle.

We tried the chicken momos and the chicken curry with carlos nan. The nan bread was super flavorful and soft perfect pair for the curry. The chicken momos come with a side of chili sauce. It was the right amount of kick to the dumpling. The  dumpling comes with 8 pieces and fresh with the tomato sauce. 

The service was nice. The employees will greet you and  pour you a cup of water. But throughout dinner they will come and swap of the plate you you don't mix the flavors. They also change the utensils as well. Excellent service from the staff to make sure we are able to enjoy each dishes flavor.

Will coome back for other dishes.
author: Bonnie C.

description:
My friend and I were stomping around the Mission on a Saturday evening encountering waitlists at numerous restaurants that our hanger would not accommodate. We finally resolved to explore the relatively new and scantily reviewed Dancing Yak, where we immediately got a table for two with no problem. The décor and paintings included vibrant purples and blues in an intriguing way, and we found ourselves among numerous couples on date night. 

Our eyes were without a doubt larger than our stomachs at this point, and we ordered all of chicken momos, dal, a classic Nepalese chicken curry, naan, and buckwheat pancakes. Momos are always a popular appetizer, but I actually could've done without them as the curries and breads were very flavorful more satisfying. My favorite item of the night was the buckwheat pancakes, made from oily and more mealy dark batter. While the food hit the spot, the service was spotty, as we had to put in a great deal of effort to flag down wait staff even though we were right in front of the restaurant and along the route from the kitchen to the majority of diners. Every time we did manage to hail a server, they sometimes appeared confused since they were not necessarily "our" server. They may have been getting their operations in order as a newer establishment. Most importantly, the food is hot and tasty and the portions large for an upscale restaurant. We packed up leftovers so our gluttony did not go to waste. The thing with Indian food is that one can easily find authentic offerings for cheap in the Bay Area, but Dancing Yak would be a fitting choice if you are craving these comforting spices but would like a classier environment.
author: Amy G.

description: While I love my protein, Dancing Yak is one place where I would gladly order the vegetarian options. Bonus points for no wait!
author: Sam W.

description: Very delicious and well-made momos, curries, veg, and other dishes.  Diners all around us were satisfied. I wish I knew where they obtain the yogurt served with meals. Try the Ice Gold Beer from Nepal. Service is very friendly and efficient.
author: Matt B.

description:
Dancing Yak sums up my life in my 20s: a lot of alcohol induced dancing and praying to the porcelain throne all morning. I prayed more in my late 20s than the 8 years in Catholic School. =/

So, when I read about the opening of Dancing Yak, I initially thought it was a nightclub. Then, I realized it's the restaurant that took over Babu Ji, Nostra, Plin, Another Money, and Conduit. In the last 5 years, no restaurant has lasted more than year in this space so hopefully Dancing Yak will turn that around?

Dancing Yak serves Nepalese fare and they have a full bar which is always a huge plus. They're currently in soft opening mode with a grand opening this Friday, May 4th. For now, they have a full menu for lunch and dinner with a plethora of apps, soups, salads, tandoori, curry, and thali. Based on customer feedback, they will shorten the menu so it's more focused and concise.

While perusing the menu, we were brought a Complimentary Nepali Snack of savory rice crispies: https://bit.ly/2I4cDZ7. 

My co-worker and I started with an obligatory order of Chicken Momo: Nepali dumplings w/ minced chicken, chives, garlic, spices, tomato sauce (8 pc - $13): https://bit.ly/2FBem2C. They were decent, though the spices were too muted for us (needed more ginger, garlic, and turmeric) and reminded us more of Chinese dumplings. The accompanying tomato sauce needed more oomph too. We were also brought a side of their housemade hot sauce which helped amp up the flavor. 

We also ordered the Pork Bhutwa appetizer w/ chili powder, garlic-ginger paste ($12): https://bit.ly/2JMreW2. The menu says, it's a pork belly cut but customers complained that it was too fatty (umm, fat = flavor!) so they changed it to a lean loin cut. It was very tough and dry but the flavor was good. My co-worker said, it reminded her of her grandma's pork adobo. 

For a shared entrée, we shared the Salmon Caju w/ cashew nut cream sauce ($22), Garlic Naan ($3.50), Basmati Rice ($3): https://bit.ly/2HHjic5.

I'm not a fan of cooked fish because most places tend to overcook fish it. However, my co-worker wanted fish so we compromised and asked the owner if we can do the caju curry with the salmon. She said, yes so I appreciate the accommodation. As suspected, the salmon was overcooked and dry BUT the deliciously rich, cashew cream sauce gave it much needed moisture and saved the dish. 

The garlic naan was fresh out of the oven - hot, soft, and fluffy with a nice garlickyness. The basmati was perfectly cooked with nicely separated grains. Both the naan and rice were great vessel for sopping up all the caju curry. 

Service was fantastic. The owner was the only one manning the FOH - engaging with customers and soliciting feedback. We were honest and told her what we liked and didn't like. She did comp the pork dish since the menu stated that it was pork belly but it wasn't. She overheard my co-worker talking about Indian ice cream and brought us out a sample of the pistachio kulfi which so good - creamy, nutty, and not overly sweet. 

Dancing Yak has a huge, festive space that can accommodate over 150+ people and even has a private dining area. The bar seems like a great place for happy hour (they will have HH specials) and there's a corner "living room" area which is good for people watching while sipping on a cocktail. 

Currently, Dancing Yak's food is at 3-3.25 stars (the spices are too tamed IMO but that's what they may be going for) but rounding up to 4 stars since they're in soft opening mode and I'm confident they'll evolve in the coming months. Best of luck to the owner on their grand opening this week!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Pretty solid Nepalese food in the Mission! The restaurant is well located with trendy decor and happy hour specials. Servers were super nice and took time to explain the various dishes on the menu.

We started with the Khaja Set, a cold appetizer sampler with a variety of salads, and the bean soup. Not everything was to my taste but it was great to try some unique items. We also got the Chicken Momos, which were tasty and came with a smooth tomatoey sauce for dipping.

For mains, we got the Lamb Curry Thali which was delicious and came with way more sides than we could finish. Our server recommended the Eggplant Curry, which was incredible as well - it was made of pureed roasted eggplant, so it had an amazing texture and deep flavor. Definitely get the Garlic Naan to mop up the sauces!

Overall great new spot - would come and try more things in the future!
author: Joanna X.

description:
DANCING! DANCING! DANCING!
duhduh nuhnuhnuh
it's DANCING YAK CUISINEEE
oooo baybeh! eattt it babeh!

lunchomatic nepalatic
CHICKEN MOMO serve a plate
spooned n forked to your mouth

yaaaa

GOAT CURRYing GARLIC NAANing
it's such a sexy platey
filled with bones n gristle yowch

it's feeding it's steaming
paintings n dope menuuu art now
author: Dan B.

description:
Wow! A hidden treasure!

We had ordered garlic naan (obvs), roti, paneer, goat curry and chicken momo's. 

Goat Curry was spectacular. Felt like my mother's cooking. 10/10

Chicken momo's lived up to the hype! Flavorful and had a little kick to it. The sauce in the middle is something I would buy bottled up.
12/10 

The ambiance was super cute. There was a little lounge area with books and it was a nice spot to drink chai and hang out.
author: Nabiha J.

description:
Dancing Yak is a new Nepalese restaurant (in the former Babuji space), boasting delicious Nepalese food, cocktails, and art. I had heard about Dancing Yak from Eater SF and eagerly decided to check it out for their soft opening on April 16 (they are officially open May 4th). I'm a huge fan of Nepalese food so I went in with certain expectations in mind, but also with a relaxed set of expectations given the soft opening. This place sets itself apart from other Nepali restaurants in the area given the more upscale feel/service and vibrant/colorful artwork hanging on every wall. Very cool vibes. If you've never had Nepalese food, you must come here and try it.

The cocktail bar was not yet opened so I'll be sure to update my review when I visit Dancing Yak after they officially open. They definitely had some kinks to sort out when it comes to service, but the food more than spoke for itself and I'm excited to see how this restaurant grows in a district ripe with excellent dining options. 

For starters, we ordered the Vegetarian Momos (Nepalese dumplings) and the Bara (lentil patty). The momos were excellent!! I often find veg momos to be lacking in flavor when compared to their chicken counterparts, but these were packed with flavor and delicious veggies. And the skin was perfectly thin and not overly doughy, which is something I often find. The tomato-based sauce/chutney that came with it was equally delicious and savory. I would highly highly recommend ordering a set of momos when you come here. Will update this review when I try the chicken momos, but I'm sure they will be just as good. The Bara was super unique, in a great way! It is a lentil patty packed with subtle flavor (ginger in particular) and reminded me of something I used to eat at home - very warm and welcoming food. 

For our main, we decided to check out the Dal Bhaat Thali platter, with fish curry. Thalis are a traditionally Indian/Nepali platter where you get to try a few dishes in smaller portions. It's a ton of fun to share these. This thali just reminded me of home - each dish was light and flavorful, and came with papad (like an Indian chip) that paired well texture-wise with the small dishes. The Daal Bhaat (black lentils dish) was very tasty. The seasonal vegetable dish was a cauliflower dish. It tasted just like how my mom makes it. But my favorite dish on the platter was definitely the fish curry - perfectly cooked, flaky fish, dipped in a delicious tomato-based curry. All too often, Nepali and Indian restaurants will serve curries doused in cream and they end up being too heavy, but Dancing Yak hit all the right notes :). 

We ordered Naan on the side and boy was it goood! It was just so soft/pillowy and came fresh out of the oven. I couldn't stop eating it. 

The server offered us complimentary dessert so we split a mango kulfi (ice cream) and a dish of rice noodles in a subtly sweet milk-based sauce with notes of cardamom. Both were tasty! The kulfi was definitely on the sweet side, while the other dish was more subtle.

Overall I enjoyed the experience at Dancing Yak and cant wait to try new things (cocktails included) and update my review once they have stabilized a bit :). I wish them the best of luck with this awesome endeavor! The Mission was lacking an authentic, swanky Nepalese dining option.
author: Sabina S.

description:
Came here with my parents and had a pretty damn good lunch. We got the chicken momo, the Special Khichidi, goat curry, one garlic naan and one buckwheat roti.

The chicken momo were super good, as you would expect from a nepali joint. The goat curry was pretty standard, and the naan and roti were both good as well. But the Khichidi really stood out. A pleasing mash of rice, lentils, and cauliflower (probably more?) with some bits creamy, some bits fried and crunchy, basically stole the show. Definitely try to get it.

I hope this place lasts, it's pretty big so it might be a hard space to fill, but their food is great.
author: Misha T.

description:
Here for a casual Friday date night. 

Ambiance was quite casual and lively. Service was okay - had a great intro and recommendation but difficult to find server during the meal. 

Food was a disappointment. Upon the recommendations of the server, we had the chicken momos (3 stars) - thick skins, okay fillings. The pork belly (4 stars) had good flavor, but a bit too dry. The Daal Bhat Thai platter (2.5 stars) with lamb was the biggest disappointment for us. It came with 2 pieces of meat (they were good though), a bowl of curry sauce and a bowl of potato curry. Would recommend ordering a la carte instead!

TLDR: cool Nepalese concept, but didn't fit our tastebuds and portion expectations.
author: Nancy Z.

description: Great place! We have been meaning to come here for a while and it was definitely worth it. Neema was absolutely fabulous! She was so attentive and knowledgeable. When she wasn't 100% sure about the wine (I asked a few difficult questions) she found out immediately and let me taste a couple. The food was great! We got the chicken Momos, cashew chicken, lamb curry, and garlic naan. All were outstanding! Can't wait to come back!
author: Maddy D.

description: Walking by on our way through a food tour experience.... we saw the name, and then smelled deliciousness. We ran across the street, and we were welcomed in with open arms. Comfortable, clean, great atmosphere.... and great service.  Nema, the server is fantastic was so amazing!!! Just incredible! And the food!!! Ahhhhhhhhh, so good. Lamb curry, eggplant, cauliflower, it's all delicious.
author: Amber B.

description:
Came in here on a Sunday and was blown away. Lots of fresh Nepalese food. Naan might be one of the best I've had. Definitely recommend the garlic. Cocktails are good too, went with an old fashioned which was quite peppery and generally delicious. The Momo's are worth visiting for. 

Best for me was the chicken dish. Just perfectly cooked, tasty chicken.
author: Michael L.

description:
I'm from India studying at UC Berkeley, and the food at Dancing Yak reminds me of food back home. Probably the best Mughlai food in SF. The butter chicken has the perfect spice level and is not too creamy or watery. The texture and tase are perfect. 

My only complain is that the plates are too small. Food that has gravy tends to spread and it becomes a little too messy if I put rice or bread on my plate. Bigger plates could go a long way.
author: Aditya G.

description:
1. Way expensive food 
2. Mediocre food. There is lot of great Nepali food around the city and bay. 
3. Frustratingly slow service. Had to wait 20 mins for food to come after order. Other tables were seeing slow service.
author: Maulik S.

description:
Really good indian food! The starters weren't that great and probably would not order them the next time I visit. 

However the main courses are full of authentic flavors of Indian cuisine. I had the butter chicken and dal makhani. Both were up to the mark and would definitely recommend. Naan, as expected, hit the bullseye in mediocrity, but I wouldn't complain since none of the indian restaurants have proper naans as we get in India.

I look forward to my next visit here and will be trying some of their Nepali dishes!
author: Akshat G.

description:
We love momos. You should definitely ask them for their hot sauce with the momos - so good. But what was really surprising was their thali with goat meat...the flavor was unique and delicious.

It's a super friendly family-run restaurant. Awesome service. We plan on coming back next week, for sure.
author: Walter T.

description:
Yikes, service here was terrible and food did not really make up for it. We waited over 30 mins after our reservation time to get seated, and in the meantime we thought we would get a drink from the bar, but it seemed they were overwhelmed as well and that took 25 mins. 

On to the food,

- chicken momos were good but dough seemed a bit undercooked.
- Dahling curry was watery and very bland.
- The eggplant dish was probably the winner. 
- garlic naan was good
- pork belly had some interesting spices on it, but a bit tough
- cocktails were pretty good

Pretty disappointed that we didn't get anything for the awful service, would have expected a free drink or app or something.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
The wait to be seated was about 10 mins. 
Long wait for food cause it is grand opening and. ALOT of people. Had to ask them a few times to see if it was ready.. mind you I was kind of hangry at that time, so the wait made me even angry! Idk if I'll come back...
author: Lulu L.

description: I came here for happy hour on a Friday after work. This town isn't a hot bed of awesome food options for happy hour but I was pleasantly surprised with Dancing Yak. My friend and I ordered a cocktail and pretty much every food item on the happy hour menu that was vegetarian. It was all very delicious and filling. The bartender was friendly, service was quick, and the design is a little funky and a little yogi but inviting. Will definitely be back for happy hour and regular service.
author: Tarah P.

description: Met a friend and sat at the bar for dinner.  Cocktails were delicious, as were the chicken momos which came with a great curry sauce.  Sadly everything else we ordered after that was bland.  I mean lacking salt, spice or any kind of flavor.  The black lentil patty, the buckwheat roti, all the things on the Thali platter and the khaja set.  Bland.  And came to the table cold.   I'd come for drinks and momos, but skip the cold bland food.
author: Nicole B.

description:
I'm not gonna lie...went there looking for Babu Ji and found the Dancing Yak instead. We were famished so decided to try and were pleasantly surprised. 

Good causal affair with good food. It was my first try at Nepalese...I found it similar to Indian yet less spicy. We got the Momo, Baal dat Thali and Chicken curry. I really liked the variety and everything was delicious. Also got the garlic naan and it was the best I've tried. The portions were perfect for two people. Our bill was a bit steep at about $70, but considering the Valencia location it's in the ballpark.
author: Claudia A.

description: Great food at a really good location. The cocktail menu is unique and every drink has a Nepalese spin to it. I would recommend family style if you have a group of friends. Definitely order the Momos!
author: Esther T.

description: Pretty good for a group dinner! Beware that the entrees are pretty large and one can be shared by two or three people, especially if you've got naans on the side. We tried the chicken momos, buckwheat roti, dhan chicken curry, and veggie samosas, as well as the nepali old fashioned cocktail. Everything tasted great although the buckwheat roti was a bit too oily for my liking. Service is friendly but food can take a while to come out (we went on a Saturday night). I recommend making a reservation as the place was packed when we went.
author: Meryam B.

description:
Dancing Yak is an incredible addition to the neighborhood. I've dined here three time already, drawn back by the food, ambience and hospitality. 

Firstly, the food - it's authentic Nepali, rare to find in SF. The flavors are subtly different from Indian and so delicious. I'd highly recommend the salt lassi with Himalayan salt and the chicken chili and chicken momos - staple dishes of Nepal and some of the best I've had. I've also tried the thali, paneer salad, chicken biryani, Kheer and gulab jamun - all delicious. The bar food at happy hour is equally good. I so appreciate the authenticity - in a sea of North and South Indian choices that tailor to American taste, this food stands out and is refreshingly different. 

Lastly, let's acknowledge the lovely hospitality. The wait staff is great. Suraksha is charming and passionate - we feel so welcomed every time.
author: Arijit P.

description:
Nepalese - and it has a wider range of offerings than expected. There's a whole long list of curries to try ranging including veggie-forward to meaty. The flavors are are on the mild/subtle side compared to what you might expect when you think of 'curries' - but in no way are bland or uninteresting. 

We actually came on a lark one night with our baby daughter, then came back the next night with my parents!  We got to vegetable MOMOs both times (8 dumplings with tasty mix of not-crunchy not-gooey just-right veggies inside, plus a tasty medium-spicy sauce).  Later, we followed with the tandoor plate (minced lamb was fab), and a few curries. Of the curries, the butter chicken is a more tomato-red than you may expect (which is great! It's distinct from 'normal' butter chicken), the okra was sautéed and had a roasted feel with some of the stringyness of okra but without the gooey consistency of most okra dishes. The eggplant curry was a scoopable consistency that you could easily spread over Naan or eat in small or big bites. We complemented it with garlic naan - which was perfectly crispy soft with generous but not overwhelming garlic. 

The cocktails were interesting and fine (we got the two made with allspice dram - 'Honey Hunter from Nepal' and 'Don't Talk Yak').. but not fantastic.  Something about the balance of flavors and ingredients. (I finished about half of mine). Perhaps these will get tweaked and improved over time. 

Dancing Yak recently opened up, so if you're looking for a no-wait kind of place with different and good food, this is great choice. Later it'll be a great choice, with a wait.
author: Stuart C.

description:
I wish I had not come here for dinner. Here is how our night unfolded: 

TLDR: bad service, super long wait times and the only good we had was stale. Left without eating.

7:30 We called them and they told they'll be able to get us a table at 8. 
7:55 We arrived and the usher told us we need to wait. 
We waited till our patience dwindled and we saw others arriving after us being seated. 
8:20 We went to the bar to get a drink the bar tender tells us that the wait for cocktails will be long as he had a long line of orders!! 
8:25 Checked with the lady again and she told 20 minutes to be seated. 
8:35 we get drinks. Drinks were good. I'll give 4/5 for the drinks
8:45 checked with the lady again and informed her we will leave if they cannot accommodate us.
8:55 we are seated. By then we know the menu backwards! We wait for someone to come and take our order
9:05 we place our order
9:25 we get our appetizer of veggie Momo's. Which tasted stale.
9:50 the waiter tells us that our food is next in line to be prepared. 

It's been 45 minutes since we placed the order and they hadn't started preparing our food yet. 

That was the last straw. We decided to leave. We asked for the check for the appetizer. The owner of the restaurant apologized and told us that it was on the house. We insisted to pay and paid the amount as we did not want to set an example that bad service maybe forgotten with on the house appetizers!
author: Milana R.

description:
This is a must location in the bay. So much culture and incredible energy in one space. 

Elements of the space I enjoyed:
- The ambiance. The restaurant as a whole is colorful, playful, with a chill vibe. LOVE the artwork too
- The lounge. In front provides a nice space to have conversation, tea and learn about Nepal. The owner (from Nepal) special ordered a book to expose the first image ever taken by a camera in Nepal 
- The full bar. Absolutely beautiful. The bartender was super pleasant, offering suggestions depending on liquor preference

Grub we enjoyed and I recommend:
- Chicken Momo
- Pork Belly Bhutwa
- Chicken Chili
- Daal Bhat Thali
- Dhading style chicken curry
- Garlic Naan (MUST GET)

We dined there for a surprise private celebration. There is a nice space in the back for a more intimate experience. The owner not only served us, but helped us set up, including a beautiful bouquet, thank you for that! Her service and kind conversation was earthy and inspiring. And to top it off, we were all blown away with the appetizers, entrees and cocktails. Every single bite had us big eyed. Unique experience, intimate vibes, cultural love. Music is also groovy AF, they have their own Spotify Playlist, what's it called??
author: Cheyenne L.

description:
Omg this place is AMAAAAAZZZINGGGG!! I can't say enough in words! You have to go for yourself to truly understand how freakin delicious it is. Nepalese food is similar to Indian food, but lighter on the flavoring. We got two rice dishes, two currys (one chicken one beef), pork belly, okra, momos, garlic naan. EVERYTHING was so so so good! 

Not only the food is amazing though. The ambiance is so cool and intimate. 

AND the service, I am a service snob, and this restaurant blew me away. The owner herself took care of our table or 13 people. She made delicious recommendations, recipes from her own family, tweaked with a little SF vibe. She is the sweetest, coolest person ever, hard working and genuine. Kudos to her for creating this amazing place.

I CANNOT wait to have an excuse to come back to the city just to eat here!!
author: S B.

description:
Edit: Updating this on Oct 1 after visiting again. Their service is up to speed now and we didn't have to wait too long this time. 

********
Loved the food although the service was excruciatingly slow, as others have pointed out. 

Great place to go with friends that you are comfortable talking to for half an hour while you wait for your cocktail to arrive. 

Seriously though, I hope they sort their operations issues soon. I'd like to come back because their food was top notch but not sure I have the patience to wait so long.
author: Sahil B.

description: I love the modern approach to Nepali food at this location in the mission. We didn't have reservations on a Friday night but were able to be seated with only a 20 minute wait. I really appreciated that the woman seating us took the time to explain and recommend a few dishes. The menu can be a bit daunting. We started with some cocktails that were good but I was hoping they were a bit more unique based on their descriptions. The momos are a must have. We also got chicken lollipops and shared goat curry with a side of buckwheat naan. The portions are huge and we were stuffed. Interesting food, friendly service, cool ambiance.
author: Yin H.

description:
Best momos in the city? Quite possibly.

The chicken momos here are not worse than the best ones I've had around. To be fair, I am a dumpling addict, but I don't enjoy any old dumpling. The momos are well-proportioned, perfectly cooked, and downright delicious. Also, sometimes the sauce is just as important, and by no means are the momos squandered by the sauce that came with it (which sometimes happens, believe me). 

While I'd be happy to go through the dishes and tell you what to order (Nepali Thali and any curry), the true star of this establishment is definitely the woman who runs the place--Suraksha. Everyone who enters and is served here can tell that she takes a lot of pride in each of the dishes, as it is her own culture that is on display, shared with each of us. Dancing Yak deserves to succeed not just because of the food and the space, but mainly for Suraksha!

Go team! Get here and eat! Also, they're open for lunch and have a happy hour...
author: Anthony G.

description:
My husband and I loved the name and were very excited about trying a new place, SO happy we did! We got chicken momo as a starter (phenomenal) the traditional Napli dish with goat curry and the Dhading chicken. The presentation was wonderful and the variety of flavors in one plate was so satisfying, it can only be described as a "happy" food experience!
We are also on our honeymoon and when we called ahead and told them they left a bouquet of fresh flowers on our table for us!
I recommend this place, from one foodie to another, you have to try this!!
author: Jessica B.

description: Absolutely amazing! Such a great find. Def get the chicken Momo and the fried paneer.
author: Affan K.

description: Food was one of the best, the ambiance was trendy and cute, but the service was extremely slow, after waiting for 45 min on our table, one appetizer came, it was the chicken lollipop but it was pink inside.. we had been waiting for the entrees for at least 1.5 hour. Then I don't know if we were too hungry or what , the butter chicken, shrimp plate, chicken momos and the naan were all amazingly delicious. Our server (sorry didn't catch the name) was very nice as well. It would have been a solid 5 stars if it wasn't that slow. Don't go there if you were hangry.
author: Kassi O.

description: Went to try some Nepalese food on a busy night on Thursday. We couldn't make a reservation but took our chances. We were seated within 10 minutes. We had their house cocktails, appetizers and chicken dishes. All very delicious!! It is a MUST try if you live around Mission area. I will go back to try their vegetarian dishes and other drinks.
author: Meesha P.

description: It was quiet on a school night but filled up later in the evening. The lamb curry and garlic naan were delicious but afterwards we realized how salty the food was. Very tasty but not sure how often we'd go. One cocktail was good, the other cocktail had wrong proportions (too much lime juice) that we should've sent back but didn't. Service was friendly and attentive.
author: kiwi l.

description: The food was great. However, the waitress was a little flakey and kept forgetting to check if things were gluten free (my gf is deathly alergic). Nobody went to the hospital and the rest of the service was good. I'll probably go back again and hopefully they'll be a little more cognizant of our needs next time.
author: Brenton M.

description:
I tried Dancing Yak on their grand opening night, and aside from a small mishap at another table (someone's naan got set on fire?!), everything seemed to go smoothly and the food was great!

My table of 6 ordered the chicken momo, Daal Bhat Thal with goat curry, chicken tikka masala, cauliflower curry, eggplant curry, garlic naan and paratha. It was the exact right amount of food. My favorite items were the momo, paratha, and chicken tikka masala. Least favorite? Probably the cauliflower curry (too buttery and there weren't many pieces of cauliflower).

I have a slight preference for Cuisine of Nepal in Bernal Heights, but Dancing Yak is definitely more spacious and ideal for large groups. They have a private room in the back as well. I imagine it'll get busy pretty soon, but love that they take reservations. I would definitely recommend it!
author: Valerie L.

description: There's a great nepalese place near my apt BUT it's in the TL. I had met up with a friend and we decided to come try out this place. It's a short walk from the 16th St. Bart station. When we came, like around 7:30, the place was full but the side near the bar had some tables. I instantly saw how understaffed they were. One of the waitresses told us we could wait at the bar and that most likely, we would get a seat in 5-10 minutes because one table had already paid. We waited like, 10 minutes and couldn't flag her down to ask if we could sit on the side tables because it was obvious no one was leaving soon. The bartender ended up being the ones sitting us. At least we got our orders in quick and food delivered. We got the chicken momos, I got the okra entree and my friend got the chicken curry. There was also a side of white rice. The momos looked a bit smaller than the ones I would get from my neighborhood restaurant. Overall, it was decent food and a bit pricier than I am used to but seeing how big this restaurant is and it's location, it's understandable. There definitely is slow service but they looked understaffed so what can you do? I wish there were bigger portions to what I ordered. Regardless, if you're feeling Nepalese food and live nearby, this may be the neighborhood place you've been looking for.
author: Michelle R.

description: Definitely recommend!  Great venue: combination of food, aesthetic and service led to a very enjoyable experience.  Momos and chana were great appetizers, and the Thali was great for dinner.  Will be back soon for sure
author: Curren I.

description:
Was really looking forward to this place based on the reviews, but it was SUPER underwhelming. There was no punch to the flavors, the meat was a little flabby for my tastes & all of the sauces were kind of watery... It was a shame as the place itself was nice & the service pleasant.

We shared the khaja set for appetizer, and I had to spit out one piece of lamb because it was just so so fatty & chewy. For mains we both had the chicken curry daal bhat thali. One of the dishes was like a very thin, green, flavorless soup. But we had no spoon & to be honest, it wasn't very appetizing so we didn't eat it. The curry component was fine but nothing special. We also shared pretty plain garlic naan. 

Anyway, we live nearby but won't be visiting again. Not worth it when there are so many great restaurants nearby.
author: Fi M.

description:
I'm afraid this place didn't live up to the hype for me. We ordered the chicken momos, the samosas, and the pork belly for a light dinner for 2.

The momos were great, and the portion size was much larger than I expected. So 5 stars for those!

The Samosas were pretty average, especially for veggie samosas. 

The pork belly was a disappointment. The meat was dry and the fat was just... fat. I would not recommend them. 

We also tried to order the chicken lollipop but it seemed they were out, and the waitress didn't tell us they were out until all 3 of our other items were in front of us. That said, she was lovely.

Probably won't be back but glad we were able to try it out.

Oh, one more weird thing - when I arrived the host sat me at a table for 2. I went to the bathroom and when I came back, my boyfriend had arrived and been sat at another table in the restaurant even though he gave them my name. Bit of confusion but no big deal.
author: Julia O.

description:
We were disappointed with our meal here. The restaurant's decor was inviting, the bathrooms a little strange-almost felt like in a display space.

Appetizers for pakora was flavorful with the sauces. The chicken momo's spice-something seemed too overpowering-the orange sauce lacked flavor.

Both entrees were disappointing yet nice presentation. The goat curry thali tray came with a black daal and potato-cauliflower and the goat curry (mostly cartilage/bones). Unfortunately, all of the items lacked flavor and salt. The daal and goat curry were very diluted and very watery. It was frustrating knowing even a dash of salt could have probably cajoled some taste and distinction of the absent flavors. Both sauces were as thin as water. 

The seek kabob also had a barely there flavor.

Next time I want Nepalese, I would probably have to go to Berkeley for it.
author: Summer S.

description: This place truly deserves all those 5 stars. Visited here because of the great reviews and was amazed by the service and authentic nepalese food.
author: Dawa T.

description:
One of the best authentic Nepalese and Indian restaurants in SF downtown. 
Well done, Guys!
author: John J.

description: Had dinner here the other night on a Wednesday with 3 friends and it was great! We just walked in and they had plenty of tables to seat us immediately. We ordered the veggie momos, curry burry, and thali veggie sampler. The food was all delicious and great for sharing. Would definitely come back again!
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Service was great! Despite the wait time they rearranged their chairs so that we could be seated promptly and checked on us constantly. 
The lollipop chicken was amazing!
But did not like the chicken tandoor or lamb aloo. They were bland and lacking in flavor.
Similarly with the chicken biriyani, the flavor was lacking and did not taste authentic. 
Getting their flavors up to mark would definitely get them to a higher rating level!
author: Maisha R.

description:
What a delightful surprise! When we went out last night, our party of 3 was headed to a different restaurant but their wait was too long-so we went walking and decided to spontaneously try Nepali food. IM SO GLAD WE DID! 

We had rose lemonade for a beverage, so refreshing and vegetable Momo to Start. They were delightful dumplings in a spicy curry sauce. Great portion and very flavorful.

Then we had the curry okra and vegetable Bhandi. Everything was shareable, interactive and cooked lovely. I do wish the waiter told us what each thing on the Bhandi was when it was set down. Cute little dishes filled with various sauces and foods.

In all, I'm glad there is a new diverse restaurant on my block that has a groovy atmosphere and innovative food.

Can't wait to to go back.
author: Terri L.

description:
I have been around a lots of other Nepali restaurants but nth compared to this one 
It started with a awesome service and the food was delicious 
Defined recommend this place, yes I will be back
author: Spandan K.

description:
Just YES! Probably one of the greatest finds since leaving NYC food heaven. Definitely coming back and adding it to one of my staples. 

So much to rave about where to start? 

First, the food is like a cross between Chinese and Indian, very heavily spiced just how I like it. It's not as heavy as Indian which is also great.

Second, there were some new unique flavors that I hadn't tasted before that really impressed me. I think a chefs duty is to bring new exotic tastes to the customer to tickle their tastebuds and that's exactly what Dancing Yak did.

Third, the restaurant experience was great. The decor was pleasing and painstakingly chosen down to the wax lotus leaf candle holders. The boss lady had great recommendations and was passionate about the food. She's also really pretty and has some smoking hot tatts on her leg. She is like exactly what I would imagine as a restaurant boss - strong, opinionated with lots of life stories.

We had the chicken moma and dhal bhat thali recommended by the boss lady. Both were restaurant specials and Nepalese staples.

TLDR : 10/10 would recommend. Get the chicken moma and dhal baht.
author: Rena S.

description: This place is incredible and my favorite Nepalese in Bay Area.  The food is exquisite, the ambiance is impeccable.  It is highly approachable from a western perspective yet holds true to its Nepali roots.  The full bar is a daring addition but the drinks are executed magnificently; my personal favorite is the "don't talk yak".  Lastly I'll finish by saying the owner is incredibly kind generous and humble.  This place will go far!  You will be seeing more of me dancing yak!
author: Mallory D.

description:
Such a lovey place to be being a Nepali and international 
Amazing interior, music was equally fun . And yes food was amazing . I had the Nepali thali which is so hard find in the Bay Area . 
Surekhya was an amazing host . She offered me free khir 
Definitely coming back for more authentic Nepali food .
author: Sairat R.

description: Delicious traditional Nepalese food.  They hand make the Momo's and Samosas fresh daily, very good.  Had the traditional dish Daal Bhat Thali which was great and the perfect size for two.  Most of all the service was excellent, very friendly and welcoming and they took the time to explain the dishes and make some recommendations.  The bill came with a card inviting us to visit Nepal and a few phrases the Nepalese language.  Hope this place does well, will be back to try a cocktail sometime :)
author: Steve R.

description: I love this place - delicious food, full bar, COMFY SEATS (it's mostly turquioise pleather banquettes instead of the awful Ikea-style stuff so ubiquitous in this city). They are open all day so you can get lunch at odd hours and dodge the crowds if you're into that (which I am). My current go-to for meeting up with somebody.
author: Amy T.

description:
Used Dancing Yak for catering an event. And I'm very happy I did.

Giving this review because this place earned it. They delivered the food right in time for lunch and set it up perfectly. The portions were VERY generous, I was surprised at how much food I got for 30 people. 
They have vegan options which is SO RARE to find on here, so I did have team members who are vegan feel appreciated that there was options for them. 
Customer service was PERFECT. I had two people from Dancing Yak deliver to food in a professional and timely manner. I will 100% recommend this place to anyone who wants delicious Indian food. 

The owner is beyond fabulous as well. One of the warmest and sweetest people I've had to work with in a LONG time.
author: Jesus B.

description:
Having tried numerous so called Nepalese restaurant that essentially have a Indian menu , I m glad to have stumbled upon Dancing Yak !! This is the go to place if you want authentic Nepalese food in San Francisco. Me and my wife really enjoyed eating here during one of our recent visits to San Francisco. It reminded me of the cuisine that I ate growing up in Ktm, Nepal. Will definitely go back to try some of their other dishes on the menu !!!

Also for other people trying this place go for dishes  that you haven't heard before at Indian restaurants, you will be delightfully surprised !
author: Avi G.

description: Delicious food! Loved it. You should definitely order the Chicken momos and the Mango lassi. We came here for lunch and the place was quite empty, which I didn't mind cuz service was great! If you really like spicy food ask for their homemade spicy sauce, you'll thank me later. It added the perfect zing to our meal.
author: Neha S.

description:
Food is good. Service is horrible! Super super slow, poorly ran. One waiter for 10 tables! 30 min for a drink. Been here 1hr 20 min and no entree's yet. Had to cancel our order and go down the street to eat. Get a new ops man. 

I appreciate the response from the restaurant. I really want this restaurant to succeed. I want to add that the appetizer was good, the server was trying his best, food looked great and hip atmosphere. I am sure there is some way to align service with the  potential.
author: Rick R.

description: We got the vegetarian momos and the Thai Bali veggie set. Food was great, flavors fresh and came out without too long of wait. Service is great. The owner out in a lot of care and served us. I would highly recommend!
author: Christine P.

description:
Our experience was absolutely terrible. We ended up sitting at the table for 2 hours until food came, and when it did it was quite average.

The two tables on either side of us ended up getting comped because their experience was so bad too.
author: Tony Z.

description: This is a great neighborhood gem and you're going to love it! First, it's a family affair here. One of the daughters checked up on us a few times and told us her dad was whipping up fresh chai for us. She later said her mom and her designed part of the menu. She said Paneer salad was a nod to Californian's love of salads, and by the way, it was fantastic. They nailed the paneer making - perfect light crips on the outside and firm sort of spongey cheese on the inside. You can feel the love in this food. Even their hot sauce for the amazing momos is made in-house. Big portions, great curries, creative cocktails and a fresh atmosphere round it all out.
author: Mark S.

description:
When I review places I try to keep in mind all factors; how was the staff, food, atmosphere, price,  etc. This place has a cool atmosphere, comfy feel. The staff were helpful, almost too helpful (we had been asked 3-4 times before the food was served if we needed anything). Unfortunately the food wasn't overly good. I ordered the chicken tandoori meal. The amount of food on the plate was not as much as I hoped for, a very small amount of rice and salad along with 4 pieces of chicken. The chicken was not good, overly dry as if it had been sitting under a heat lamp for hours. 

Based on that I likely won't be returning. I still ate the food and wasn't full :( 
I actually ate again when I got home 20 minutes later. And for $18 I have to say I was disappointed. 

I can't speak for the rest of the food or quality so this could be an isolated case however, I won't be returning.
author: James C.

description: Food was ok. Service was super slow. This was for my friends' bdays. And it was quite disappointing. For context, this is my first one star on Yelp.
author: Alex G.

description:
I've come to Dancing Yak I'd say about 10 times so far, as I work nearby.  It has a nice ambience with colorful art on the wall and decorations.  The restaurant is family-owned with family members managing the restaurant and serving.  I've always found the service excellent and friendly.  

My favorite dishes are the Butter Chicken and Daal Baat Thali.  Butter Chicken is prepared well and has a rich sauce that's addicting.  The Daal Baat Thali comes with a few different foods such as lentils, rice, and vegetable sides.  You choose the meat and usually I order the Chicken Curry.  It's nice because it has variety; so you can get different kinds of food even if you order one dish.

Yak has a fair number of people in the evenings, but at lunchtime, there's still many open tables.  I hope Mission folk patronize this place for lunch more because we need more restaurants staying open for lunch.  The restaurant in the same location that preceded Yak (Bhabu Ji) wasn't open for lunch.  Pauline's and Tawla which are nearby are also closed for lunch. 

The music here is also really good even if I can't place what genre it is; it sounds like a fusion between Indian or Nepalese music and Western.  Its music taste rivals that of Burma Love, which is right across the road.  Which brings me to a comparison.  Having lived in this part of the Mission for a year, and close to BL, I've gone there usually twice a week.  Obviously I like Burma Love to go there that often, but I also find that the dishes there often taste alike.  It's also gotten to be really crowded all times of the day.  Dancing Yak has as similar ambience, more consistently good service, and in my opinion, the food tastes better.
author: Bob C.

description: Everything we ate was rich in flavor and extremely fresh tasting. The vegetable momos were paired with a delicious spicy sauce. The garlic naan was very garlicky and delicious. We were already planning our next visit before we even left.
author: Brooke A.

description: Delicious food, friendly staff, and a nice ambiance. My friends and I had a great time!
author: Katherine S.

description:
I'm giving 4 stars now but it could easily go to 2. Why? Staffing. I understand it's hard to flip on a dime when your restaurant becomes hot. But the seriously prolonged waits for even cocktails is a problem. Much delay can be forgiven if a good cocktail is in hand. The key is IN HAND!

Cocktails are about a B-   There's not much creativity demanded for vodka based concoctions, and there were a lot of those on the menu. The riff on an old fashioned lacked Peychaud's butters and was consequently a bit plain, even with the slight kick from the pepper infused bourbon. My mezcal based cocktail was pretty good (a solid B), with some interesting flavors, but not an awesome marriage of flavors. 

The wine list was A+. Delicious!

Food was a solid B. Great presentation, well prepared, and fairly tasty. But nothing extraordinarily compared to other prices. However pricing is a A, so this place is a solid value. 

The interior looks recycled and amateurishly designed. Except the bathrooms, those are great. Except how much dinner time do you spend there?!?

So we enjoyed our experience for the most part, minus the gross delays especially for the cocktails. For reference we spent over two hours here for a 1 hour meal. We are not at Atelier Crenn here!

NOTE: after the first version of this review posted, which posted before we left the restaurant, the owner thanked us for the review and responded to the service by significantly reducing our bill, which was already very reasonable. We love owners who appreciate our reviews, even if they aren't stellar reviews without critiques. Based on that experience and our dining experience, Dancing Yak is definitely worth your time and dining dollars.
author: Gregory Z.

description:
I have pretty much Tikka Masala-ed my way though this city. Yes I just verbed tikka masala.

I've never had Nepalese food, and stumbled in here on a cold, hungry night. Seeing the chicky tikki on the menu, I obviously went for it as a safe bet. 

WHAT IN GODS NAME IS IT THAT TIKKI I WANT IT EVERY DAY. It's sooooo creamy. But, also lighter than traditional Indian? I dunno how they did it. 

And the garlic naan???? I'm dead. See you soon Dancing Yak, I hope I can order you from my couch soon for Sunday Tikka night.
author: Nicole M.

description: Place is amazing. Came with some friends pretty randomly. The Bhindi Tarkari and the Dhading style Chicken curry are soooooo good. Also the Lachha Paratha is great!
author: David B.

description:
Went there for a birthday dinner. The hospitality and food were just great! We got a private room for a big party. Didn't know we could get a closed room for an outing with friends in SF:)
For dinner, the butter chicken and salmon curry were delicious! Will go again very soon.
author: Japna C.

description: First time trying Nepalese food. It was soooooo good. My husband and I started with the spicy paneer (so good) and the samosas (average). We then went on to share the Dhading style chicken curry (Delish!) and a side of garlic Naan (crispy & perfect). It's been 3 days and I'm already planning our next trip! Definitely try this place next time you're in the area.
author: Diana R.

description:
I feel bad giving this review... 
the people are wonderful, the vibe is awesome but the overall service... was terrible. 
The food...was mediocre to say the least. 
My highlight was the garlic naan but everything else... no!  
They were very kind to us to compensate for their mistakes but unfortunately it may not be enough for us to return.
author: Roberta B.

description: Excellent momos and dinner. Cocktails are creative and delicious. You will not be disappointed. Fast service, very nice staff. I've been here a few times. A+
author: Patrick C.

description: I came hungry, and I was stuffed by the end! I had asked for a sweet drink and was recommended "Avalanche in Everest" (mango vodka, pineapple juice, lassi, and honey ). It was delicious. Then we ordered the chicken momo (which looked like potstickers). My friend and I each ordered our own daal bhat thali (I ordered lamb, she ordered veggie). I couldn't finish all of the food on the plate! Definitely worth it. Great experience and amazing service!
author: Angela K.

description: Wow I actually found a place that made me like carrots, peas, and lentils. My mom would be so proud. This place has the most fragrant and well balanced Nepalese food I have ever had. The meat was tender, the curry was full of flavor, the rice was perfectly cooked and loose. Nothing was overly salty or oily. I highly recommend the Daal Bhat Thai. It gives you a bit of everything.
author: Diane Z.

description:
The food was hit or miss. I had the Khaja Set and Daal Bhat Thali with lamb. Each plate had some decent parts, and some things that I didn't want to take more than one bite of. Generally, the things that tasted bad seemed like the spices were applied incorrectly. (And maybe someone would like it, but it just didn't match my palate? I tend to have pretty broad tastes.)

But then there were two unfortunate standouts: the lamb in the khaja set was extraordinarily tough, and the center item in the khaja set didn't even seem like food (it was crunchy and barely tasted like anything).

I wasn't a huge fan of the music, which I'd describe as "generic lounge". I also didn't think that the projected video of various nature night sky scenes added much.

Instead of bringing my appetizer and entree, they brought the appetizer twice. It took a little while for them to figure out that this mixup also meant that my entree wasn't coming. Fortunately, they deducted 25% from my check to compensate.

The owner and bartender seemed like nice people, so I'm disappointed to have this feedback.
author: Nick H.

description: Great food, really good ambience and very courteous staff. Definitely a must visit for anyone who enjoys Himalayan cuisine.
author: Aseem G.

description:
Slowly I'm starting to eat here everyday so watch out; you may get hooked like me!!
I'm starting to swing by on my break now just for cocktails since the restaurant has such an inviting atmosphere. There's also a lounge section with bean bags so if you start dancing too much you'll have a safe place to crash and NOT burn.
author: Travis S.

description: Love the momo's and curry dishes. Attentive service and great for group dinners / sharing.
author: Rosa L.

description:
The Nepali food was mad delicious.

Ambience and setup is great.

And our host, Suraksha was kind and generous.

Definitely coming back!
author: Ngawang G.

description:
Great place! We were debating whether or not to come, but ended up just going for it. We were pleasantly surprised when we walked in. The decor is very cool, modern with cool psychedelic artwork. Top music choices, awesome choices. Family run business. The daughter seems cool and picks the art and music.

Cocktails were good and interesting. 

Food is very flavorful. Some of the best Momos we've ever had. The chicken curry was delicious. The potatoes and cauliflower were also good. 

I would be interested in trying their lunch combo.

Will be coming back!
author: Julien B.

description:
It's so hard to find good authentic Nepali food in the Bay Area as lot of restaurants overdo it and put too much curry spice in it!! Ambience is great and their craft cocktail is awesome! 
Try their pork belly and avalanche in Everest!! 
You won't regret it!!
author: Bimarsh S.

description:
To start off and build credibility- I was born and raised in Nepal. I'm naturally very picky when it comes to Nepali food anywhere and today I was really impressed by the Dancing Yak.

What tends to happen at a lot of Nepali restaurants is that the cuisine gets diluted by the Indian options on the menu. As a result, most places focus on making the popular items like butter chicken tasty and don't pay attention to their Momo's. 
I don't think you can call yourself Nepali restaurant w/o paying attention to the staple that everyone who knows the cuisine will expect. The chicken momo at Dancing Yak is great (I would hope that they make a few adjustments to the dough to make it even better) but the MOMO SAUCE is amazing. So simple and has a great kick, I inhaled the Momos today. 
I also had the dal bhat set, and all its components were awesome. Simple and done well, didn't overcompensate for flavor by making it heavy and greasy. And this is why I was impressed. Most Nepali restaurants that I've been to in the US try to do the most, this restaurant keeps it casual and keeps the prices reasonable. I felt like I was eating home cooking. Thank you.

I gave a 4-star for now, because I think there's some improvement to be made. But I'll be a regular and hope to revisit the rating :) 
Oh and as an added bonus, the ambiance is great and the staff is super friendly. If you're looking for flavorful Nepali comfort food surrounded by friendly faces, go to this place!
author: Spriha S.

description:
One of the best restaurants I have ever been to. All the food we got was amazing- samosas, bara, lamb shish kabob. Daniel was an awesome server and bartender, very friendly and hospitable!

But the star of the show, the show stopper, show stealer- the butter chicken. It was one of the best dishes at any restaurant I've ever had. I can't stress enough how delicious the butter chicken was. I ate so much I gave myself a stomachache and it was worth every second. 

I'm coming to San Francisco just for the butter chicken. Amazing.
author: S B.

description:
I found a real Nepalese restaurant in SF with very quite and perfect decorations. Foods are super. Cocktails- Don't talk yak and Avalanche in Everest are awesome.
Everything including dining table to wash basin to commode are unique and matching. 
In love with this restaurant.
author: Sujan P.

description: This was just OK. I was a little disappointed and I don't think the glowing reviews are merited. The chili paneer and chicken momo appetizers were the best part of the meal, but the curries we ordered as our main course were super bland. I don't think I'd go back.
author: Julie R.

description: Having been to Nepal I know what real Nepalese good tastes like. They do a good job here! First time I visited they were overwhelmed with business and were slow getting us food. I think they had just opened and we're still working out the kinks. Second time I went the service was wayyyy better but the daal was a bit watery. All in all I'd highly recommend it! Get the Nepali thali and momos. Both are very typical in Nepal. We are Thalis all the time on the Annapurna circuit trail and in our hosts home. Enjoy!!
author: Katie J.

description:
I always have a great experience at Dancing Yak! Each dish offers a unique bite of something special and you can't really go wrong here.  I would recommend the Himalayan salt lassi and Chicken Briyana or Chili Chicken.  

Definitely a place I will keep coming back to.
author: Chris R.

description: I love trying new things and, considering how much I enjoy Indian food, I was ready to be enamored with Dancing Yak. They do several things really well - the staff members are really friendly and prompt, the ambience is nice, and it feels good to support a family-owned business. The food, though, isn't amazing. We tried the Lamb, chicken and goat + a Nepalese dumpling appetizer. The dumplings were great, but none of the main dishes blew us away (or pleased the palate).
author: Kelsey L.

description: Amazing food, great service, prices good for value! Have been here many times and it only gets better
author: Kouris K.

description:
This place was great!

Chicken MOMOs were excellent -- really delicious sauce 

The thali was delicious, nice balance of flavors

Staff was very attentive
author: Jesse E.
